title: I'm finding it harder and harder to stay interested in League in 6.2
body:
Why?

Personally I think the pre-patch and this season is a disaster.  I'm going to use dot points to try to make this concise and easy to follow.

* Towers.  Ohhhhhh boy, towers.  Not one person, not a single person, in real life or on these boards or even on a stream, never have I ever seen anyone say 'yo these towers are too strong, let's nerf' or think it would be a good idea/good for the game.  I get that you wanted to make games shorter, but this wasn't the way to do it.

* You made a conscious decision to make games shorter buuuuuut where are the adjustments to late-game champs?  Irelia, Ryze, Nasus, Cass - you've made absolutely no adjustments to these or any other champs that rely on farming all game to hit max power.  All you've done is reduced tower strength and increased death timers which screams of laziness.

Side note: Ryze and Cass have still seen play in Korea for various reasons, but the risk is huge when taking these champs (less so with Ryze) but they are played **_in spite of_** the game changes, not because of them.

* Increased death timers has only lead to more risk-averse, punishing gameplay and moronic win conditions.  Korea has been the most prominent in this area, but solo queue is equally as frustrating.  It's always been the case that getting caught late game probably leads to a loss, but that has shifted about 10-15 minutes and it just means that people, especially pros, play way, way safer in the 'late game'.  It also unequally and unnecessarily places a lot more importance on what happens in the first 5-10 minutes of the game.

* Despite all of this, these changes have failed, for the most part, to _significantly_ reduce game length.  All they've done is made the game more punishing, frustrating, and worse to watch, especially Korean pro League.   A lot of the games (and series) have been incredibly boring and it's a real shame.  I have gone from watching LCK at every single opportunity last year to having it on in the background this year and not bothering most of the time.  The hyper risk-averse gameplay combined with 'oops fight one time we lose' is utterly mind-numbing and BORING.

* The turret trades at the start of every pro game are a joke.  Yes I'm aware this occurred before this season, but it wasn't ALL the time like it is now.

* You do a massive overhaul of ADC items but the big winners have been bruisers.

* You think that CDR is more important for AD champs than AP champs and leave 40% CDR totally unattainable without buying an item that is terrible on most champs (grail).

* There are so many unhealthy and toxic champs in the game right now, and with only 6 bans, I struggle to find playing against or _with them_ any fun.

* The current state of Fiora, Tahm Kench, GP, Graves, Kalista is an embarrassment to the game and to your balancing team.

* You introduce new mastery Keystones that break the damage output of previously balanced champs like Swain and Karthus, but instead of nerfing their damage output you nerf their utility - **_what?_**

* You then nerf the Keystones but LEAVE THE PREVIOUSLY NERFED CHAMPS IN THEIR NERFED STATE instead of compensating them.  This is the very definition of being 'Sejuani'd' and you should be fu#$ing ashamed of this because it shows your favouritism towards keeping certain champs in/out of the meta.

* The Riot post that admitted to keeping Sejuani 'Sejuani'd' **proves** your favouritism and destroyed a lot of people's confidence in your supposed impartial desire to have every champ be a viable pick.  This is utterly disgraceful, imo.

* Still 3 bans for each team despite the champ pool growing exponentially since we went from 2 to 3 bans (and even _that_ was long overdue).  This is **_REALLY_** overdue.

* The new player experience is still atrocious.

* The removal of mana pots and in turn, taking something interactive and making it passive (increased passive mana regen) has removed an interesting piece of decision-making from the game, particularly in the laning phase.  I HATE this change.

* The Juggernaut update did nothing but make those champs less fun to play against than before.  Darius is more binary than ever and Garen's whole 'Villain' deal is just an uninteresting and non-interactive flat damage buff.  Kindred has this down pat - making a choice for who to potentially increase your power from is a far, far better way to achieve the same result.  Playing Kindred feels way more rewarding because of this one aspect alone.

* Your champion reworks in general are... special.  Very, very special (and not in a good way).  Some of them work, most of them ratchet that power creep dial up to 11.

* Games feel less carryable than ever before.  Comebacks feel less possible than ever before.

* Warding changes but no 7th ward-only item slot for pinks.

* Illaoi is a hot mess of a champion and you've made no attempt to make her any better.

* Thunderlord's, especially on assassins.

* Keystones in general.

* It's not just me, a lot of people I know are having a lot less fun with the game than they did last year.  The broken champs, the punishing gameplay, the over-emphasis on early game decisions (and mistakes), the state of AP CDR itemisation, the turret nerfs, the incredibly lazy 'whatever it takes to make it happen' adjustments to reduce game time without consideration for the game as a whole, the boring pro games (especially in Korea - RIP) the list just goes on and on and increasingly I'm finding other things to do with my time because logging in and playing in this state of the game is just not enjoyable anymore, and worse still, nothing looks like it's going to change anytime soon.

EDIT:  Wowowowow 463 upvotes, 401 comments and 10.3k views?? HOLY BALLS.  I never thought so many people would agree with what I had to say (or at least some or most of it), but having said that I'm also **not** surprised given the state of the game right now.  I've probably now read every single update to the thread and overwhelmingly people are supportive of the points raised.

Here's the thing:  I didn't write this post to get a red response like a lot of people might think.  I did it purely to vent and raise issues with the game that are bothering the f@#$ out of me and to give **feedback**.  That is, after all, what this board is about, is it not?  Riot won't respond to this thread because of the tone of my post, I know that, but that's probably not important.  It would be nice if they acknowledged some of the points raised, but the unfortunate truth is that they probably won't.  What _is_ important is that they see the thread and take it on board.  463 upvotes??  That is insane for what is essentially a state-of-the-game thread.  Surely it just can't be ignored...

I agree so much with all of OP's complaints about the recent "games should be shorter" theory. The weaker towers are a terrible idea. All you're doing is punishing people who are trying to learn the game and need tower support. And people who are trying to expand their champion pool. Why/how on Earth would anyone look at League, and then make changes that make the game _worse_ for new players?

I stopped playing League because it just feels like a more "pretentious" version of HotS. Games are made to be as short as possible by making snowball borderline broken, it punishes you when you do well (bounty system), and there's not even alternating maps/objectives. I returned and loved the Tank Meta when Cinderhulk came out, because it felt different. It was the game I had known and loved for so long, but then it faded quickly, first by item nerfs, and then by dumpstering the convicted. In Heroes, at least, balance prevents bad people who synergize with good talents from getting nerfed.

Can't wait for masteries and runes to be replaced with talents, though. (/s)

It seems to me this trend started before Heroes of the Storm was even fully fleshed out, though it seems likely that Riot's reaction to Hots has exacerbated this. I find there is a similar case to be made for Dota 2's impact on Riot. 

On the one hand, Hots has 10 different battlegrounds, which equates to 10 different game modes, something Riot tries to match with their rotation of featured game modes, yet they don't commit to this by supporting the permanent alternate game modes they currently have beyond token mentions in the patch notes once in a while. Hots also has short fights centered around who can chain cc and burst the enemy team down faster, and shorter games in general (although Blizzard claims to have taken steps to reduce snowballing, with longer death timers and lower scaling at early levels, but I don't see a significant difference). Yet, even before Hots, Riot has been making moves such as nerfing then reworking Soraka away from a kit that thrived in extending team fights to a burst heal oriented mage that can be fairly easily picked off with % missing health damage (or be the first in a Darius dunktrain, and now she is getting nerfed again http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/l0A1He0N-current-pbe-soraka-nerfs). We have also seen a general neglect, as Hot Cousin observes, of champs like Nasus who depend on long games to scale. 

On the other hand, Dota 2 is a deeper and more complex (with longer game times), thus more difficult to learn and master, game, which is something Riot  also seems to be attempting to imitate with the marksman reworks and itemization changes that have lead to their increasing viability in multiple roles. There is also their Mordekaiser experiment that I view in similar terms of an attempt to increase the variability of bot lane duos away from marksman/support (something I am in favor of, by the way, coming from a support POV). And, of course, we will have to see how this continues to develop as the immobile mage rework/itemization changes are revealed. Nevertheless, the problem I see with this is that they are essentially attempting to pull LoL in two conflicting directions: Hots' simplified, short, brawling-focused battles across numerous game modes, and Dota 2's complex, long, strategic battles developed and balanced exclusively for a single game mode/map (and I am aware custom game modes exist, but as they are user created and balanced, they don't have a place in this discussion, which is concerned with official development and release).

Yet the one thing they don't take a cue from Hots/Dota 2 regarding is treating all players equally regardless of gameplay preference. What I mean is that Hots allows for champion mastery in ranked, unranked, and vs ai games, yet League has yet to enable mastery in anything beyond PvP SR. Likewise, Dota 2 allows for random cosmetic item drops (their version of skins) in ranked, unranked, and vs ai games, yet, as LoL's champion mastery is currently exclusive to PvP SR, the soon to be released Hextech crafting is denied to everyone but an arbitrarily (in that Riot has devoted its time almost exclusively to that one game mode and basically neglected the others, though that does not mean we have to do the same) selected group of players.

Agree with every point, though i would like to add some points:

 - The rather high increase in gold from CS early on makes CS leads more snowbally
 - While shutdowngold overall is higher, the global distribution makes it way harder to come back in lane, and the 'assist-spreas', which made targets that had alot assists more valuable, have been removed, so unless you opponents only have solo-kills, the total shutdown gold is lower than befor
 - Turret gold has been increased, so takeing early turrets snowballs more
 - Overall damage, especially burst, has been favoured by masteries, items and neutral buffs -> more snowbally as mistakes more likely lead to death rather than retreat.
 - Riftherald offers even more resources to take for a team with an early lead
 - Darkness is upon us! Warding is now jungle+supp only, as laners can't keep even a single ward up constantly till 18, and if your jungler neither gets trackers nor sightstone, say goodby to your vision. 
 - The low vision leads to passive and stall gameplay, as any active action without vision is just to risky, which can easily observed in proplay.
 - Running around in darkness always leads to harder snowballing.
 - The overall increased costs of end-tier items, mostly with above 1k combine costs, makes it really hard to atain coregear when behind and leds to a hard power discrepancy between a fed and a behind champ.
 - The high cost of Rabadons really hurts mages that rely more on ap-scaleings. Most mages that are/were effective had very pen focused builts due to high base-mediocre scaleings. Aditionally, nearly every ap-mid in competetive rushes abysal or roa, or both, as those two have been buffed while all other ap-items have been nerfed.
 -  many great items have been removed/reworked, and their nich is now empty....
 - ...which forces many champs into crit builts while they had valid options to opt out of RNG befor - hello built-deversity!
 - The LW changes remove it as the save midgame powerspike that was important for adc to have some impact when behind, while totally invalidateing any armor items later on(with mastery you get over 50% pen!), still rendering tanks rather usless once 5+items are reached(though people don't notice that, as you rarly get so much items unless insanely fed these days)
 - The crit itemisation gives ADC all the tools they need to snowball an advantage really hard
 - Mercurial is just stupidly strong right now. Such a massive active should come at more costs.

It is often spoken in business that smarter people have less common sense. it is a fact that many of the pinnings of game mechanics are built upon common sense factors. This idiom versus fact becomes a paradox.

A rioter stated in January that recent changes have questioned some long held anchors of LoL game design. I am assuming that the current devs are very smart, since the common sense factors were being questioned. This is the root of all the problems you listed.

We can talk about turret diving as a prime example. The reason stronger turrets make for a better game is that the risk:reward ratio is more reasonable. It is a common sense factor. The enjoyment of watching a turret dive is knowing that there is a high risk. Now, we have no risk turret dives, and the result is boring. The thrill of turrets was nothing more than the tradeoff of damage given versus damage assuredly taken. That is the player and viewer perception that incites emotion. That effect is also common sense.

So, we have devs that are too smart, so the product becomes more stupid. Interesting twist right? The only solution is to hire devs that understand this balance, and that have the power to enforce it.
